Sure, here is the VPython code that illustrates the horizontal projectile motion experiment as requested:

```python
from vpython import *

# Screen Settings
scene.width = 700
scene.height = 400

# Parameters
initial_height = 5  # Initial height of the ball (in meters)
g = 9.81  # Acceleration due to gravity (in m/s^2)
v0 = 10  # Initial velocity of the ball (in m/s)
dt = 0.01  # Time step

# Objects
ground = box(pos=vector(0, 0, 0), size=vector(20, 0.1, 10), color=color.green)
ball = sphere(pos=vector(0, initial_height, 0), radius=0.5, color=color.red)

# Initial conditions
ball.velocity = vector(v0, 0, 0)

while True:
    rate(100)
    
    # Update position
    ball.pos.x += ball.velocity.x * dt
    ball.pos.y += ball.velocity.y * dt - 0.5 * g * dt**2
    
    # Update velocity
    ball.velocity.y -= g * dt
    
    # Check collision with ground
    if ball.pos.y <= ball.radius:
        ball.velocity.y *= -1  # Bounce with an elastic collision
```

This code sets up the VPython animation for the horizontal projectile motion experiment with the specified initial height, initial velocity, and acceleration due to gravity. The ball accelerates downward under gravity and bounces off the ground elastically. The animation will continue running indefinitely until interrupted.

If you want to update the initial height, you can change the value of `initial_height`, and the animation will restart with the new initial height.
